Award.AwardTitle: Phonetic Characteristics of Epenthetic Vowels in Palestinian Arabic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the phonetics of several sub-dialects of Arabic spoken in Israel. The main focus is on the acoustic properties of vowels and the ways that native speakers perceive them. A distinctive feature of Arabic is that in casual speech, a great many words can optionally be pronounced with extra vowels: for example, the Arabic word for "girl" can be pronounced as either "bint" or "binit". There is evidence that the optional vowels are different from regular vowels, but the details of these differences have not been investigated in depth. The project consists of data collection, elicitation, and experiments designed to identify the nature of these vowels, their acoustic properties, and how speakers perceive them.

Phonetics experiments will be carried out at several Israeli universities, with Arabic-speaking university students as participants. The project will train U.S. graduate students in acoustic speech analysis, experiment design and phonetic fieldwork.

The project will have both practical and scientific implications. A better understanding of the phonetics of Arabic may help advance the state of the art in automatic speech recognition, speech to speech translation, speaker identification, as well as the teaching of colloquial Arabic. Scientifically, the optional vowels have posed difficulty for theories of language due to certain puzzling properties, for instance that they never appear in stressed syllables. A better understanding of the acoustics of these vowels can help resolve such puzzles. More generally, the project will contribute to our understanding of the mental and physical processes underlying human speech production and perception.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “Phonetic Characteristics of Epenthetic Vowels in Palestinian Arabic” had two main goals: 1) to improve our knowledge of dialect variation among Arabic speakers of the Eastern Mediterranean region; and 2) to improve our knowledge of the mental processes underlying speech production and perception more generally.

In collaboration with linguists from Tel Aviv University and the University of Haifa, we recorded speech samples from over 100 speakers from dozens of different cities, towns and villages in Israel. These recordings were segmented and annotated by a team of student research assistants, creating a rich dataset for acoustic analysis. Analysis of the dataset is ongoing, but already we have discovered previously unreported dialect differences in the pronunciation of certain vowels.

Several of the experiments focused on a class of words that can be pronounced either with one or two syllables --- for example, the word for ‘clothing’ can be pronounced libs or libes. We found that the extra e sound in the two-syllable version is acoustically different from regular e sounds, suggesting that it is represented differently in the speaker’s mind. We also found that, in speech perception tests, people were faster to process words when the extra syllable was present. This suggests that the function of the added vowel may be to improve perceptibility.

This project resulted in the creation of resources that will continue to benefit Arabic linguistics research for years to come. As part of the experiment design process, we created a machine-readable lexical database of Levantine Arabic. The project has also contributed to the development of human resources for Arabic and other linguistics. The project employed over a dozen graduate and undergraduate research assistants, who received training in skills such as experiment design, phonetic analysis techniques, experimental protocols, fieldwork, and using acoustics software.
